title: 110_hr5710
content: The Act is titled the "Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System Authorization Act" and includes definitions. The Act defines key terms such as Authority, Engineering report, Plan, Secretary, State, and System related to the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System. The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System delivers water from the Ute Reservoir to various cities and counties in the State. The Ute Reservoir is located on the Canadian River, created in 1962 by the Ute Dam. The System includes major components identified in the engineering report as the "Best Technical Alternative." The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System delivers water from the Ute Reservoir to cities and counties in the State. The Secretary may provide financial and technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, and constructing the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System. Financial assistance must be used in accordance with a cooperative agreement and cannot be used for activities inconsistent with the System or for irrigation water supply facilities. The Federal share of the total cost of the System under the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System Act shall not exceed 75 percent. No funds can be used for construction until a plan is developed and environmental requirements are met. Title to the infrastructure of the System will be held by the Authority or as specified under State law. The Authority is responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs of the System. They will develop a plan with the Secretary to establish rates and fees for beneficiaries to ensure proper maintenance and water delivery. Administrative provisions are also outlined. The Secretary may enter into contracts, grants, or cooperative agreements to carry out the Act. A cooperative agreement with the Authority will provide financial assistance for planning, design, and construction of the System, specifying responsibilities for cost-sharing. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, constructing, and operating the System. The Secretary shall consult with relevant entities for preparing any biological assessment under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Act does not affect State water law or interstate compacts related to water allocation, nor does it grant non-Federal entities Federal water rights. SEC. 6. Authorization of Appropriations: An amount not greater than $327,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary for carrying out this Act. The amount will be adjusted to reflect changes in construction costs, and any unexpended funds at the end of each fiscal year will be retained for future use. Amounts made available under the cost-sharing requirement will not be reimbursable or returnable to the United States. Passed the House of Representatives on June 19, 2008. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
